liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: EY chief economist Cherelle Murphy says she would have been "very surprised" if the RBA held the cash rate steady today, but warns we shouldn't expect to see rates stay on hold at 4.35% forever. Speaking to finance presenter Alicia Barry earlier, Ms Murphy says the risks of inflationary forces remain but it's not clear if the RBA will raise rates again this year. You can watch her full breakdown of today's rates decision below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank's decision to lift interest rates had very little impact on the Australian share market today. The ASX 200 closed 0.3% lower at 6,977 points, around the level it was trading at before the RBA rate hike. Healthcare and technology stocks were among the best-performing stocks, like WiseTech Global (+2.6%), Healius (+5.4%), Pro Medicus (+3%) and Nanosonics (+2.5%). At the other end of the spectrum, banking, mining and lithium stocks drove the market lower, including Westpac (-2.7%), Chalice Mining (-5.5%), Allkem (-4.4%), Liontown Resources (-4%) and Pilbara Minerals (-3.7%). Despite the negative finish on the ASX, it still fared much better than other stock markets in the Asia-Pacific, with the Nikkei, Hang Seng and KOSPI down 1.2%, 1.5% and 3% respectively.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What affect do we expect this to have on the housing market? In particular the markets outside of Melbourne and Sydney. - Marcus vn. I'm sure there's a lot of people wondering this Marcus. As is often the case in economics and finance, it depends who you ask, although no-one would tell you rising rates are a positive for real estate! CoreLogic's head of research Tim Lawless: "Lower confidence could act as a drag on housing market activity, denting buyer demand at a time when advertised stock levels are rising across most regions. A rebalancing between buyer demand and advertised stock levels is likely to take some heat out of the housing upswing, which has already been losing some momentum, at least at a macro level, since the monthly rate of value growth peaked in May. "Higher interest rates also imply a further diminishing in borrowing capacity as lenders continue to assess borrowers using a three-percentage point serviceability buffer. "While growth in housing values is likely to slow further, it's hard to see prices going backwards over the near term. A shortage in housing supply, record low vacancy rates and a lagged flow through to purchasing demand from record levels of overseas migration should help to keep some upwards pressure on home values." PropTrack's senior economist Eleanor Creagh with a similar view: " Record levels of net overseas migration, a challenged rental market, limited housing stock and a slowdown in the completion of new builds are offsetting the impacts of substantial rate rises and the slowing economy, with home prices continuing to lift. "This additional increase in interest rates may slow the current pace of home price growth but is unlikely to deter these gains, with strong population growth, tight rental markets and a housing shortfall fuelling further price rises." But SQM Research managing director Louis Christopher told the AFR earlier this week that there comes a breaking point for the property market, and we may be near it: "Since the market is finely tuned it might only take one rate rise to create an additional slowdown in housing. The risks rise substantially [of] a period where the market goes into another downturn."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What effect will the rate rise have on property prices?

children.content: What affect do we expect this to have on the housing market? In particular the markets outside of Melbourne and Sydney.
- Marcus vn

I'm sure there's a lot of people wondering this Marcus. As is often the case in economics and finance, it depends who you ask, although no-one would tell you rising rates are a positive for real estate!
CoreLogic's head of research Tim Lawless:
"Lower confidence could act as a drag on housing market activity,
denting buyer demand at a time when advertised stock levels are rising

across most regions. A rebalancing between buyer demand and advertised stock levels is likely to take some heat out of the housing upswing, which has already been losing some momentum, at least at a macro level, since the monthly rate of value growth peaked in May.
"Higher interest rates also imply
a further diminishing in borrowing capacity
as lenders continue to assess borrowers using a three-percentage point serviceability buffer.
"While growth in housing values is likely to slow further, it's
hard to see prices going backwards over the near term
. A shortage in housing supply, record low vacancy rates and a lagged flow through to purchasing demand from
record levels of overseas migration
should help to keep some upwards pressure on home values."
PropTrack's senior economist Eleanor Creagh
with a similar view:
Record levels of net overseas migration, a challenged rental market, limited housing stock and a slowdown in the completion of new builds
are offsetting the impacts of substantial rate rises and the slowing economy, with home prices continuing to lift.
"This additional increase in
interest rates
may slow the current pace of home price growth
but is unlikely to deter these gains, with strong population growth, tight rental markets and a housing shortfall fuelling further price rises."
But
SQM Research managing director Louis Christopher
told the AFR earlier this week that there comes a breaking point for the property market, and we may be near it:
"Since the market is finely tuned
it might only take one rate rise to create an additional slowdown in housing
. The risks rise substantially [of] a period where the market goes into another downturn."

items.synopsis: Israel says it would consider "tactical little pauses" in fighting to allow for aid and the release of hostages, but has rejected calls for a ceasefire, while Israel's neighbour Jordan says "all options" are on the table. Follow live.Â

title.children: Israel open to 'tactical little pauses' in Gaza assault for aid, release of hostages

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Defence Minister Richard Marles has reiterated Australia's position on calling for a "pause" to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza. "We have made clear the right that Israel has to defend itself in the face of the 
attacks that were undertaken by Hamas back on the 7 October and obviously those attacks were directed at innocent people", he told the ABC's Afternoon Briefing. "We have also been really concerned about the humanitarian situation in Gaza, about the plight of innocent 
Palestinians, the vast bulk of whom have nothing to do with Hamas", he said. "And it is really important that front and centre in terms of the way in which Israel goes about its work is the safety of innocent Palestinians in Gaza. "That is why we have been 
calling for humanitarian assistance to be allowed into Gaza. It is why we have been calling for a pause to allow for humanitarian assistance to be provided and we will continue to advocate on behalf of the humanitarian issues which are impacting Gazans." When asked about the legal action launched by Palestinian humanitarian groups to access records on Australia's arms exports to Israel, and whether Australia had provided weapons to Israel since October 7, Marles said the matters are before the courts and he would not go "into details". "But let me simply say, Israel has not sought any weapons from Australia, and we have not provided any", he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Marles says Australia has not provided weapons to Israel since October 7, reiterates position on humanitarian 'pause'

children.content: Defence Minister Richard Marles
has reiterated Australia's position on calling for a "pause" to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza.

"We have made clear the right that Israel has to defend itself in the face of the 
attacks that were undertaken by Hamas back on the 7 October and obviously those attacks were directed at innocent people", he told the ABC's Afternoon Briefing.

"We have also been really concerned about the humanitarian situation in Gaza, about the plight of innocent 
Palestinians, the vast bulk of whom have nothing to do with Hamas", he said.
"And it is really important that front and centre in terms of the way in which Israel goes about its work is the safety of innocent Palestinians in Gaza.

"That is why we have been 
calling for humanitarian assistance to be allowed into Gaza. It is why we have been calling for a pause to allow for humanitarian assistance to be provided and we will continue to advocate on behalf of the humanitarian issues which are impacting Gazans."
When asked about the legal action launched
Â

by Palestinian humanitarian groups to access records on Australia's arms exports to Israel, and whether Australia had provided weapons to Israel since October 7, Marles said the matters are before the courts and he would not go "into details".
"But let me simply say, Israel has not sought any weapons from Australia, and we have not provided any", he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: France, China and the UAE's ambassadors to the United Nations have amplified demands for a ceasefire in Gaza after an emergency Security Council meeting. French Ambassador Nicolas de Riviere said "the humanitarian effort which is taking place now is insufficient". "They are still fighting. It should stop. We need a truce, a sustainable and durable truce," he said. "It should lead to a ceasefire. But we need a truce first to provide humanitarian access." United Arab Emirates Ambassador Lana Nusseibeh echoed the calls for a ceasefire, saying "there are a number of innocent lives under the rubble today". "Without a cessation of hostilities or some kind of humanitarian truce that is immediately implemented, far too many civilians have already lost their lives and far too many more will continue to lose their lives unless that is put into place," she said. China's Ambassador Zhang Jun said "no one is safe" as aid workers and journalists are killed. "Palestinian civilians are also deprived of necessities essential to their survival. In the midst of this catastrophic situation, we emphasize the need for the Security Council to act with urgency and adopt a meaningful and actionable resolution," he said. "We call for an urgent humanitarian ceasefire. â€¦ This is desperately needed to enable full, rapid, safe and unhindered humanitarian access." Paris will host an international humanitarian conference for the civilian population in Gaza later this week as it looks to coordinate international efforts for the Israeli-occupied Palestinian enclave. Diplomats said the conference in Paris on Thursday would also look at setting up a maritime corridor to use sea lanes to ship humanitarian aid into Gaza, but also to see how ships could be used to help the wounded evacuated from Gaza. The United States is pushing hard to arrange pauses in the conflict to allow in aid rather than a full ceasefire, arguing, like Israel, that Hamas militants would just take advantage. "We're trying to get more trucks through," said Robert Wood, deputy US ambassador to the UN. "This is a difficult situation and we're trying to do the best we can with the situation on the ground, so it's going to take some time. "We're trying to [prevent] this war from spreading, dealing with the humanitarian situation on the ground â€¦ and trying to get the hostages out." Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Durable truce': UN envoys from France, China, UAE amplify demands for a ceasefire

to the United Nations have amplified demands for a ceasefire in Gaza after an emergency Security Council meeting.

children.content: French Ambassador Nicolas de Riviere said "the humanitarian effort which is taking place now is insufficient".
"They are still fighting. It should stop. We need a truce, a sustainable and durable truce," he said.
"It should lead to a ceasefire. But we need a truce first to provide humanitarian access."
United Arab Emirates Ambassador Lana Nusseibeh echoed the calls for a ceasefire, saying "there are a number of innocent lives under the rubble today".

"Without a cessation of hostilities or some kind of humanitarian truce that is immediately implemented, far too many civilians have already lost their lives and far too many more will continue to lose their lives unless that is put into place," she said.
China's Ambassador Zhang Jun said "no one is safe" as aid workers and journalists are killed.

"Palestinian civilians are also deprived of necessities essential to their survival. In the midst of this catastrophic situation, we emphasize the need for the Security Council to act with urgency and adopt a meaningful and actionable resolution," he said.
"We call for an urgent humanitarian ceasefire. â€¦ This is desperately needed to enable full, rapid, safe and unhindered humanitarian access."
Paris will host an
international humanitarian conference
for the civilian population in Gaza later this week as it looks to coordinate international efforts for the Israeli-occupied Palestinian enclave.

Diplomats said the conference in Paris on Thursday would also look at setting up a maritime corridor to use sea lanes to ship humanitarian aid into Gaza, but also to see how ships could be used to help the wounded evacuated from Gaza.
The United States
is pushing hard to arrange pauses in the conflict to allow in aid rather than a full ceasefire, arguing, like Israel, that Hamas militants would just take advantage.
"We're trying to get more trucks through," said Robert Wood, deputy US ambassador to the UN.
"This is a difficult situation and we're trying to do the best we can with the situation on the ground, so it's going to take some time.
"We're trying to [prevent] this war from spreading, dealing with the humanitarian situation on the ground â€¦ and trying to get the hostages out."
Reporting with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Three Palestinian human rights groups have launched legal action in the Federal Court of Australia seeking to gain access to records on arms exports to Israel, according to a statement from the Australian Centre for International Justice who is supporting the application. Al-Haq, Al Mezan Centre for Human Rights and the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights said they are seeking "access to all permits allowing the export of arms and weapons to Israel that have been granted by the Minister for Defence since 7 October". "Australia's role in exporting arms material to Israel must be exposed. If Australian-made weapons are being used against Palestinian civilians, our clients and the public deserve to know", Rawan Arraf, executive director at the Australian Centre for International Justice (ACIJ), and solicitor for the Palestinian human rights groups said. "Countries providing arms to enable Israel's brutal violence against the Palestinian people must be transparent. And Australia must not be complicit in that violence", she said. "We know that hundreds of permits have been issued in recent years, but the Australian government keeps the basic details secret: what items are being exported, who is making them, what are they used for?" It is the first legal challenge attempting to shed light on arms exports permits in Australia, ACIJ said. "We are seeing the makings of a genocide unfold in front of our eyes", Issam Younis, director General Secretary at Al Mezan Centre for Human Rights, said. "If Australia is selling Israel the means to commit that genocide, it would not only be an unspeakable horror committed against the Palestinian people, it would breach Australia's obligations under international law and its own rules around arms exports." The ABC reached out to the Department of Defence for comment but has not received a response at the time of publication.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian human rights groups launch legal action to access records on Australia's arms exports to Israel
